newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo aluminium futures plunge, eyes on FOMC.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo aluminium futures plunge, eyes on FOMC.

text.p: Tokyo yen-based aluminium futures finished mostly at their limit-lows on Tuesday, hit by stop-loss selling triggered by the dollar's renewed decline, traders said.
"Now, we're watching the FOMC meeting, which should determine the dollar's further direction," said one trader, referring to the U.S. Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee later today.

Benchmark April 1998 shed six yen to 190.4 yen per kg, the contract's low since it was launched on April 25. Other contracts also finished at their limit-lows, except for the February contract that pared its loss to 5.9 yen by the close.
The dollar sank on Tuesday to below 113 yen in Asian trade from above 115 yen early in the morning.

Traders said the metal's weakness on the LME during the Asian trade also depressed the yen-based futures. Three months aluminium was quoted at $1,648/1,652 at 0655 GMT, down from $1,653 at the kerb close in London.
One LME trader said: "We've seen quite a lot of Japanese buying because of the yen's strength. But players are testing the strength of the support at $1,650."
Estimated volume was 4,169 lots, bloated by arbitrage trade by trading houses between the LME and TOCOM. It stood at 2,216 lots on Monday.
